author: @Susan-xg7qn

text:
Having lived in China for 30 years as a foreigner, I can tell you a few things.

Yes the law says to carry your passport. However, the police in my city have repeatedly told me not to. They know who I am and if it gets lost or stolen, it's more hassle for them than for me!

Bullshit, VPN's work through wi-fi. Unless you are using a crap app. VPNs are NOT banned in China. I bought mine here years ago.

There is no way you can turn up and jump on aa train. You must book in advance. And the express trains don't go everywhere.

Your visa information is out of date.

You clearly know little about real Chinese food.

You don't need both WeChat and Alipay.I only have Alipay and have never had a problem paying for anything. All places are legally obliged to accept cash!

This video is full of misinformation, downright errors and ignorance, Another idiot who has been in China ten minutes and thinks he's got it all down pat. And just promotes advertising.

text:
My wife was headhunted by one of the provincial govts to spearhead the R&D dept of one of the local biotech firms there. We'll be heading out later this week to formally meet up with the reps from the provincial govt and the company's senior mgmt, before relocating there end of April. They said if you're an expat and have a legit need to use a VPN to access, say, Google services, nobody's gonna bat an eyelid. That's a relief coz I'll need to get some work done while we're there.

The locals on Xiaohongshu recommended we download Amap - it's in English and it shows how woefully outdated Google Map is especially for county-level cities.

Our last trip to Guangzhou, Macau and HK was a few years before Covid hit, during the summer school holiday. The crowd was CRAZY, especially in HK where it was literally elbow-to-elbow.

author: @ritah777

text:
Welcome to China, where you can explore and experience the real China firsthand. This is a brief summary of my video, and if there are any areas that need improvement, feel free to share your feedback.

01-When traveling in China, it's essential to carry your passport, as you will need identification for things like taking the train or purchasing park tickets (Chinese citizens usually carry their ID cards, and even if they forget to bring them, knowing their ID number can suffice. We also have electronic ID cards, but their use is not yet widespread).
02-Google is difficult to use in China, and Google Maps is not updated promptly in the country. Typically, people in China use Amap (Gaode Maps) or Baidu Maps for navigation.
03-China is very safe, and pedestrians are usually happy to help you. If you need assistance, you can also ask the police. It's perfectly fine for women to go out alone, as the safety level in China is extremely high.
04-When traveling, it's responsible to buy insurance for yourself. It's a way of taking care of your own well-being.
05-China's ride-hailing app is Didi, which is similar to Uber and very convenient. In fact, many years ago, Didi acquired Uber's China operations.
06-Of course, for apps like maps, ride-hailing, and translation, you'll need a SIM card. Both of Beijing's airports offer SIM card sales services. After landing, you can ask any staff member, and they will guide you to the appropriate store to purchase a SIM card.
07-When visiting China, you must experience a high-speed rail (HSR) trip. With a maximum speed of 350 km/h, the high-speed rail network connects every city in China. Experiencing the world's largest and fastest high-speed rail network will be a wonderful experience. (Of course, don't forget that you'll need your passport to take the high-speed train.)
08-China currently has a population of 1.4 billion, and there are many travelers during holidays. So, it's best to avoid traveling during Chinese holidays for a more comfortable experience. Of course, you can first visit some less popular destinations and wait until after the holidays to visit famous attractions, making your trip more enjoyable by avoiding the peak crowds.（The best season to visit Beijing is during September and October.It's best to avoid July and August, as it's the summer vacation period and the hottest time of the year.）
09-Since 2024, China's visa policies have seen significant changes and relaxations. Please make sure to visit the relevant websites to check the latest updates before your trip.
10-I recommend trying the local cuisine from different regions of China. However, if you find the food unfamiliar, don't worry—Chinese cities are full of familiar Western chains like KFC, McDonald's, Burger King, and Starbucks, so you'll never have to worry about going hungry.
11-It is recommended to book international hotels, which can be easily found on booking websites. If necessary, you can call the hotel in advance to confirm whether they accept foreign travelers.
12-In China, credit cards are rarely used, and mobile electronic payments dominate everyday transactions. Even cash payments are becoming less common. Therefore, it's highly recommended to learn how to use Alipay or WeChat Pay, as these mobile payment platforms make transactions incredibly convenient during your stay in China.

text: It's hard to make an overarching statement about when are the best times to go to China as it's so vast and climates vary from region to region. It all depends on where you are going and what you want to see. For example, if you want to see the dreamy yellow rapeseed fields in Wuyuan, Jiangxi, you should go in mid to late March; if you want to see the romatic autumn colors of Hangzhou, Suzhou and Nanjing, you should go in late November. Also summer is a great time to go to the western parts of China such as Yunnan, Qinghai, Gansu and Xinjiang as weather is mild. If you want to see Tiger Leaping Gorge and avoid the wet season, its best to go before June. It is safe to say that all should try to avoid chinese hilodays though.

text:
The followings you mentioned in your video is not really accurate :
1) China is a "Secretive" country??  You have been manipulated by your country's government. 
2) Passport required in a convenient store??  I never had to show my passport when I bought from convenient stores in Beijing. 
3) VPN banned in China?  I do not think so. Many locals also use VPN.
4) You make it sound like China's so called "great fire wall" is preventing you use Google and that is so terrible. 😱 China can similarly use "National Security" as a reason to ban Google/Facebook/etc.,  just like the USA uses "National Security" to ban garlic from China, Huawei, EV cars, etc.!! 😂😂😂
5) Guests staying in small hotels have to register with the Police?? Maybe in remote areas in China? But most foreign tourists to China do not visit remote regions of China. In fact, many places I visited in Beijing,  I only see local tourists, hardly any Western tourists.
6) China is a very friendly country, with lots of ancient sites to visit. Cost of living is low and people are helpful. Do not be influenced by lying politicians and media.

text: actually china government has declared hotel cannot use any excuse to refuse foreigners to check in , especially when they said you need to register at police before checking in, just tell them you dont need to register and they cannot refuse you to check in.
author: @zhaoqingli5885

text: The two subway stations as your example are bsically a place and the place plus a character (-xi) meaning "west". They used to be like "Chegongzhuang West" so westerners can comprehend but it's not useful when you say them to a Chinese person. So in recent years all the English names were changed to the exact pronounciations to hopefully solve the problem. At the end of the day, it's better to learn some direction word before you travel to China, like dong - esat, xi - west, nan - south, bei  - north.

author: @maxxiewang8284

text: Do you know why foreigners must use the passport as ID.? Simple the passport is a standardized international format document that is issued by the traveller's countries. It has many anti counterfeit features. Driver's licences from other countries are not standardized and may not contain English or security features. As well each state or province in Canada, Australia, USA and many other countries each issue their own driver's licence. I think that these are the reasons only a passport is accepted as ID.

text: As a chinese, the VPN is actually not legal, but not literally illegal. But if you want to use it, and do not want to do some dangerous things then no one would give a shit. The police won't bother to arrest you, so actually nobody cares.
author: @galahadray

text: For some second tier cities and others, many hotels still need a license to accept foreign tourists. I once was in zhengzhou, and they couldn’t check me in because their hotel didn’t acquire the license to take foreigners. So I had to cancel that hotel and book another hotel that has the license
author: @okwatever3582

text: VPN is legal if you use a registered one by the government for business purposes - but those will not be private and have surveillance.  Personal VPNs are not "legal" but they can't really police people who use it.
author: @NateGGdog

text: Or if for a short period of time, just keep using your overseas phone but have the roaming pack on. That way, you can just use your phone like in your own country and no need for VPN.
author: @faehuang2268

text:
@NateGGdog  
The reason I said that is because I have a friend working in the land office, which is a government department, she is using VPN. They call those Accelerator apps, which are actually VPNs. If China really want to ban it, no one could use it.
author: @zeissiez

text: @okwatever3582  maybe it has taken effect yet.
author: @zeissiez

text: ​ @NateGGdog  是的，我在中国偶尔也会用下载的加速器，通过加速器能链接VPN，才能使用到你们的一些软件，观看到国内无法看见的视频😊
author: @IQA1689

text: ​ @zeissiez 还没有哦，我正在使用VPN，是下载某个应用程序带来的，虽然是非法的，但只要不危害国家的行为都不一定会管理你的
author: @IQA1689

text: It is illegal, but in most cases the police will turn a blind eye. Unless you are reported by someone else
author: @hamusutaw

text: @hamusutaw  看来你很了解我们国家，事实确实是这样，警察秉承着多一事不如少一事的想法，不会对非法使用vpn而找你，但如果是危害到国家社会的行为，警察会找你
author: @IQA1689

text: It’s more like a grey area, technically it’s illegal, but no one cares if you stay in a low profile. Yelling around to others that you are using a vpn is not a smart move😂😂😂

text: I also experienced the issue you mentioned about Alipay payments not going through. Later, someone told me that it was because the store hadn’t enabled support for credit card payments. Generally, slightly larger vendors will have this service enabled, so there’s no need to worry too much. The solution is to link a debit card. Hope it helps.

text: ohh this would make sense, but we did have debit cards linked to Alipay not credit cards but maybe it's a similar kind of thing! :)
author: @Joel_Emilia

text: ​@Joelfriend the reason is because the smaller vendors are using their personal account instead of a business account. Credit card companies such as Master card or Amex would see this as a bank transaction and not a merchant transaction ans therefore decline.
author: @passby8070

text: China's card organization is called UnionPay. Compared with Visa or MasterCard, the handling fee is very low, usually 0.6%, while Visa and MasterCard require about 6%. Therefore, many stores are reluctant to accept Visa or MasterCard cards
